_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Calumet Lubricants Company-Shreveport Refinery has a long-standing commitment to employee and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention such as safety training and incident investigation.  Safety is considered in the design, construction, operation and maintenance of our processes.  Calumets policy is to implement reasonable control to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  In the occurrence of a release, our trained emergency response personnel shall respond to control and contain the release.  The facility has experienced two accidental releases in the past five years.  The first release occurred under the ownership of Pennzoil-Quaker State.  The unit is no longer used under the business plan of calumet Lubricants.  The second release occurred in the Lube Oil Hydrotreater.  This was due to running a heater with no flow for 30 minutes under normal  fuel gas operating conditions.

OVERALL RESPONSIBILITY

The Plant Manager has the overall responsibility for ensuring that our facility operates in a safe and reliable manner.  This responsibility includes overseeing the implementation of the elements of our risk management program is appropriately developed and implemented, our Plant Manager has assigned the role of Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program to a staff member with the necessary background, training and experience.  The Director of Quality Management, acting with the authority delegated directly from the Plant Manager, has the responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) RMP elements and the elements of Occupational Safety and Health Administration?s (OSHA?s) PSM program (where applicable), as required under Section 68.15 of RMP rule.

The following sections identify the specific responsibilities foe each aspect of our risk management and process safety management programs.

2 HAZARD ASSESSMENTS

The Enviro

nmental, Health and Safety Engineers have the responsibility for: (1) ensuring that offsite consequence analysis for each regulated progress are consistently performed and documented in accordance with Section 68.20 through 68.39 and (2) selecting the scenarios that will be reported in the facility RMPlan as required under Section 68.165.

3 PERVENTION PROGRAM

The Environmental, Health and Safety Engineers have the responsibility for ensuring that the facility has an integrated, effective and compliant prevention program that meets EPA RMP (Sections 68.65 through 68.87 if the RMP rule) and OSHA PSM requirements.


3.1 Process Safety Information 

The responsibility for the process safety information (PSI) (Section 68.65 of RMP rule) is divided into three areas.  The PSM/RMO Coordinator has responsibility for process chemical information, the Process Engineer has responsibility for process technology information and the Plant Engineer has responsibility for equipment information.  The PSM/RMP Coordinator also has the responsibility of ensuring that all of this information is readily accessible for use.

3.2 Process Hazard Analysis

In accordance with Section 68.67 of the RMP rule, the PSM/RMP Coordinator has the responsibility for ensuring that process hazard analyses (PHAs) are scheduled, conducted, and documented by training personnel for all regulated processes.  The PSM/RMP Coordinator identifies candidate PHA team leaders from within the facility and ensures that they receive appropriate training before leading PHAs.  The PSM/RMP Coordinator may utilize outside contractors that lead PHAs when appropriate.

3.3 Operating Procedures

In accordance with Section 68.69 of the RMP rule, the facility?s Supervisor have the responsibility for ensuring that complete and accurate operating procedures are in place for regulated processes.  The Supervisors work closely with the PSM/RMP Coordinator to develop and maintain the facility safe work practices.  The procedures are

stored in the plant electronic document control system.

3.4 Training

In accordance with Section 68.69 of the RMP rule, the Operational Supervisors have the responsibility for: (1) ensuring that operations employees receive and understand training applicable to their specific jobs and the associated processes and (2) documenting the training.  The PSM/RMP Coordinator has the responsibility for ensuring that all facility employees receive and understand training in safe work practices applicable to their jobs.  The Maintenance Manager has the responsibility for: (1) ensuring that maintenance employees receive and understand training applicable to their specific jobs and the mechanical integrity program and documenting the training.

3.5 Mechanical Integrity    

In accordance with Section 68.69 of the RMP rule, the Plant Engineer has the responsibility for developing the mechanical integrity program with specific emphasis on written procedures, equipment and instrumentation inspection/test programs and documentation, and equipment deficiency resolution.  The Maintenance Manager also has the responsibility for implementing the mechanical integrity program and maintenance training.  The Purchasing Clerk working with the Purchasing Manager insures that appropriate quality assurance procedures are followed for all types of equipment acquisitions, installation and repairs.

3.6 Management of Change

In accordance with Section 68.69 of the RMP rule, the PSM/RMP Coordinator has the responsibility for the overall management of change (MOC) program; however the Plant Manager, the Operational Supervisors, and the Plant Engineer have responsibility for ensuring that the overall MOC program is effectively implemented in their area.

3.7 Pre-Startup Program

In accordance with Section 68.69 of the RMP rule, the PSM/RMP Coordinator has the responsibility for the overall per-startup review program, which is closely related to the MOC program.  However, the Operational Supervisors ha

ve the primary responsibility for ensuring that this program is effectively implemented before affected operations begin.


3.8 Compliance Audits

In accordance with Section 68.69 of the RMP rule, the PSM/RMP Coordinator has the responsibility for ensuring that compliance audits occur at least every three years and are documented to verify that the prevention program of working and meets EPA/OSHA requirements.

3.9 Incident Investigation

In accordance with Section 68.69 of the RMP rule, the PSM/RMP Coordinator has the responsibility for designing and managing the incident investigation program, including tracking resolution of investigation findings and recommendations.  the PSM/RMP Coordinator also has the responsibility of ensuring that only trained personnel lead our investigation.  Each area supervisor has responsibility for ensuring all incidents in their area are reported and investigated and the investigation findings are resolved, documented and communicated to the affected personnel.

3.10 Employee Participation 

In accordance with Section 68.69 of the RMP rule, the PSM/RMP Coordinator has the responsibility of involving employees in the planning and implementation of the facility?s prevention program elements.

3.11 Hot Work Permits

In accordance with Section 68.69 of the RMP rule, the PSM/RMP Coordinator work closely with the Operational Supervisors and Maintenance Manager, has the responsibility of developing and maintaining the facility?s hot work permits program.

3.12 Contractors

In accordance with Section 68.69 of the RMP rule, the Plant Engineer has the overall responsibility for the contractor; however, the Maintenance and the Purchasing Clerk are responsible for ensuring that the requirements of the program are implemented.

4 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM    

In accordance with Section 68.69 of the RMP rule, the PSM/RMP Coordinator has the responsibility for: (1) designing, implementing and maintaining the facility?s emergency response plan, (2) e

nsuring that all associated training is conducted and documented as necessary, (3) coordinating the site emergency response plan with the community emergency response plan, and (4) responding to local emergency planers/reponders when questions arise.

5 RMPLAN PREPARATION AND SUBMISSION

The PSM/RMP Coordinator is responsibility for preparing and submitting the RMPlan for the facility (after review and approval by Plant Manager) as required under Section 68.150 through 68.185 of the RMP rule.

6 RMPLAN COMMUNICATION

The Plant Manager or his designee has the responsibility of providing RMPlan information (other then the required EPA submission) to employee and the public as required under Section 68.210 of the RMP rule.
